Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates President Trump's impact on cutting illegal immigration in half.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the assertion that illegal immigration has been cut in half.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the decline in apprehensions between May and August is representative of overall trends in illegal immigration.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that apprehensions at the U.S.-Mexico border in fiscal year 2019 were more than double the total in fiscal year 2016 and almost triple the total in fiscal year 2017.
Falters at times: The claim falters by cherry-picking data from a specific time period to support its assertion.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the decline in apprehensions between May and August that are not addressed in the claim.
Understate: The claim understates the actual increase in apprehensions under President Trump when measured over a longer period of time.
